title: User Authentication on Earable Devices via Bone-Conducted Occlusion Sounds
author: Yadong Xie (Beijing Institute of Technology), Fan Li (Beijing Institute of Technology), Yue Wu (Tsinghua University), Yu Wang (Temple University), ...
relevance_why: The paper introduces novel biometric authentication methods that might inspire audio-based user authentication systems, enhancing applications relevant to Haohe's work in audio processing and enhancement.
background: This study focuses on authenticating users of mobile devices using unique sounds produced by dental occlusion detected via earbuds.
contribution: This paper introduces the TeethPass+ system, which utilizes bone-conducted sounds from dental occlusion to achieve secure user authentication, achieving a high accuracy of 98.6% and resisting 99.7% of spoofing attacks.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods primarily relied on air-conducted sounds or visual biometric features, which are more susceptible to spoofing and environmental noise.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves by focusing on bone-conducted sounds collected through earbuds, providing a secure and unobtrusive method for authentication.

key_innovation: TeethPass+ uniquely leverages the acoustic characteristics of dental occlusion sounds, which are inherently distinct for each individual due to the unique properties of their teeth and bone structure.
real_world_impact: The approach could significantly enhance mobile device security and user convenience, offering a practical solution to biometric authentication in everyday settings.
limitations: The paper does not mention specific limitations but relies on user cooperation for occlusion events.

new_terms.bone-conducted sounds: **Bone-conducted sounds** refer to sounds transmitted through bones, which can be detected through sensors or microphones placed near the ears, providing an alternative to traditional air-conducted sound detection.
